reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Unreal 2: The Awakening
Original Release: 2003
Genre Tags: FPS; Action; Sci-Fi
My Overall Grade: A-
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 8-12 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Fans of the intellectual property; Nostalgia chasers
REVIEWI personally was thoroughly surprised by how much I enjoyed Unreal II: The Awakening. There is actually a decent sci-fi narrative in there; albeit one that is a bit cliché. And the characters actually have personalities that manage to be mildly interesting. Mix that in with classic Unreal FPS gameplay and you get a pretty enjoyable experience.

The narrative will escort you from mission to mission (level to level), as you explore various worlds in the vastness of space to accomplish your goals.  In between each mission you return to your spaceship where you can interact (mildly) with your crew and arrange your armament for the next mission.  Having conversations with your crew allows you to gather background information and expands on some of the lore aspects.  In this way, there are some parallels with the early Mass Effect games.

The different missions will take you to diverse environments with various objectives, but the core gameplay doesn’t evolve much throughout the game. However you will be able to unlock new weapons and armaments as you progress, which allows you to keep things fresh as you finish up the campaign.

One main complaint with Unreal II: The Awakening is that the movement speed is much slower than in other Unreal games. To be honest, it didn’t bother me that much. Luckily, if it does bother you, there is a way to increase the speed of the game using the console.

So it is true that Unreal II: The Awakening isn’t perfect, but I still really liked the overall experience quite a bit.  I think if you enjoy sci-fi FPS games with decent narratives, and need something new to play: this is a good game for you to consider.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText: Unreal 2 starts very real, introducing your character, an ex-marine that patrols space for the Terran Colonial Authority with his cozy little spaceship, a funny pilot and a hot female companion (oh and the techie that gives you a bunch of new guns and mods after each mission). The dialogue is fun and the graphics holp up very well but the gameplay is slow and the loading times ridiculous (maybe it has something to do with my system but playing on 'hard' means you will see more of the loading screen than the actual game even when returning to a quickload). LOADING-STANDBY-INITIALISING...The psychodelic intro is nothing like the game. It was probably hard to top the creepiness and sense of alienation you had in the original, as well as it's speed and agility.  Still, the game has enough variety in the settings (very different planets and climates) and the weapons (very cool stuff including a flamethrower, turrets, and even a spiderthrower) to make it worthwhile.

reviewText: One of the last of the old-fashioned 'second generation' of FPSs on PC has mature gameplay without the complexities of more modern titles. Like many shooters from 2002-04 (such as Doom 3), its perceived flaws were more a question of originality as we headed toward more complex games like Half-Life 2, something that console shooters of the day like 'Halo' were never tarnished with. This is all of course, nowadays irrelevant. Imaginatively pretty graphics, atmospherically slower pacing, and a story with characterisation ahead of its time blesses this game with somewhat alternative priorities. It's a lot of nostalgic fun, and a great purchase for especially those who aren't extraordinarily familiar with FPSs.

reviewText:
Unreal 2 was amongst the first games to use Unreal Engine 2, Epic's technology that for years rivalled with id software's own engine. Still, after the first Unreal we had to wait 5 years for this and 2003 was just a year before 2004, the year when a lot of big names appeared; each offering something new in terms of technology (Far Cry, Doom 3 and Half Life 2, just to name a few).

Interestingly, the developer was Legend Entertainment, the guys behind the expansion pack of the first Unreal game (the company has since gone defunct) and it is a shame they could only come out with a generic shooter. While graphically the game was amazing it had little to do with Skaarj, the main antagonist species we fought so hard in the first episode. The story now is very different (but then again Quake 2 had nothing to do with Quake 1, right?); it revolves around an artifact our marine hero is set out to retrieve.

Gameplay-wise Unreal 2 is quite exciting: with John we regularly return to his ship to converse with his companions who can prepare us for the next mission. This hub area has free roaming characteristics until the moment you commence your next mission which is very linear. We visit several planets; all with its own visual theme (we have deserts, snowy areas and even an alien spaceship here) just to  make the gameplay more interesting.

Too bad that there are too many cutscenes (the generic dialogues make them boring after a while) and for some unknown reason the game only has very generic weapons. Where is the Flak Cannon we have grown to like? Here you have rifles, shotguns, grenade launchers - all too generic even with their alternative fire mode.

The game offers a decent, 9-10 hour long campaign but not multiplayer. I understand Legend came out with an expansion just to add the missing feature to the game. Still, Unreal 2 is a mixed bag. Its unique weapons disappeared from the sequel and while the story was interesting there was not much to go on with the Skaarj. The voice actor for the main protagonist was a definite miscast.

It runs well, though. There are some error messages upon launching the game but using Windows XP compatibility mode can solve all the problems. I am upvoting it mainly for sentimental reasons (after all, it was a good pastime before the new generation of FPS games were released in 2004) but perhaps you are better off with the Gold edition of the first game.

reviewText:
This game doesn't invalidate the full Unreal collection, but before buying it, I would certainly make sure that it saves you money without U2, because you should not pay money for this game.

Upon starting the game, you will be walking around, get very board with the slow walking speed, then hit Shift to speed up, only to discover that your slow waddle was actually your running speed when you start barely moving foreward. The running speed is unacceptably slow. Another reviewer, Resi, provided the following advice in their review:

Access console using ~
Type BeMyMonkey
Type setspeed 2

Whether this helps the game, I don't know.

Your weapons are very weak and extremely difficult to aim. The reticle often seems to have a very loose association with how your bullets wil actually fly and this cupled with the accuracy problems and slow movement makes this a VERY frustrating game to play through. START ON EASY! I learned the hard way.

Your efforts are rewarded with a story that is predictable from start to finish with no subtlety or spice to make the journy worth it. You fight through generic sci-fi facilities and planets, killing generic shooter enemies (aliens with guns, humans with guns, bugs) with the Skaarj enemies that made the original so memorable rare and watered down. For comparison, the original Unreal barely had a story, but it explained what was going on on Na Pali with such subtlety that you didn't care. It could be the story of a man trying to survive, or a freedom fighter, or something in the middle based only on your interpretation. Instead, we have a muguffin hunt in space.

If you have it, try the cheats above. I will. If you don't, remember, DON'T PAY EXTRA FOR THIS GAME! There are so many good shooters on Steam, you shouldn't have to waste your time with this one.

reviewText:
I love this game so much.

It still looks good, and it still plays well. I still love the sound effects and particles. And the sections of game where you have to 'hold the line' for a certain amount of time are just made so much more fun by two things.

1. You get to place down force-fields and direct soldiers and place down turrets in an effort to cover the areas where enemies are going to attack you from.

2. There's a cheat that lets you have as many sentry turrets or force-fields as you want.

There are a lot of cool levels in this game. Just play it, you'll love it if you love FPS games.

reviewText:
Perhaps the least known game of the Unreal series - for a reason. It does not feel like Unreal, does not sound like Unreal, does not even look like Unreal. There is just one alien race and three names of corporations reminding you of the other games of the series.


Not everything in this game is bad. Graphics are really nice for a 2003 game, and you fight in a wide variety of different environments, from a standard desert military base to the internal organs of a huge planet-covering alien creature. The TCA Atlantis, your own spaceship, has many nice details in its rooms.


Unfortunately, it lacks all the best aspects of the first Unreal. Maps and missions are very linear and predictable. Your movement in the bulky mech suit is clumsy and slow. The way of combat is quite different, not necessarily bad but not appealing to the fans of fast FPS. Background music isn't as impressive as in the first U. Storyline is OK but also quite short and flat. You won't feel the same mysterious atmosphere that made the first Unreal so great.


Want something like Unreal? A fast-paced survival FPS? Do not buy this.

Want a generic sci-fi tactical shooter? You might like this, although I'm pretty sure there are better alternatives.

Overall grade: 4/10

reviewText:
I would give this game a 'meh' rating if it wasnt for two things. I could overlook the annoying voice acting, the unoriginal/uninteresting story, the boring characters, and the generic level design, if it wasnt for these two simple things:

1. The movement speed of your character is the slowest I have ever encountered in any video game. Ever. This defats the whole purpose of the unreal franchise, since its trademark is dodging and jumping your way through hordes of enemies, evading their oncoming fire. Instead, I'm backpedaling frantically, desperately spewing bullets into my enemies' faces as they outrun and swarm me.

2. The gun loadout in this game is incredibly boring and lackluster compared to the other unreal games. instead of ten unique and highly creative weapons, you simply get a standard military loadout and whatever guns that your enemies drop. Probably the most interesting weapon I've encountered is the grenade launcher, simply because its gets 6 kinds of ammo and the ability to switch between them at will.

So yeah, those are the gamebreakers for me, and adding all the stuff I mentioned before just makes this game not very enjoyable. The ONLY reason you should get this game is if you're a big fan of the Unreal franchise and want to brag that you've played all of the games.

reviewText: It's... decent. It isn't arena style combat like the UT games, but it is a bit of a mix between the original Unreal and the Tournaments. The graphics look nice for it's time, but obviously don't look great today. The guns are kind of cool, and there are a few challenging and fun to fight enemies. Really, it's just hard to say anything is majorly wrong with the game, but there isn't much they did super well. The guns are kind of cool, and if you played Oblivion, the main character's voice should sound VERY familiar. The biggest flaw with the game is probably the story, it starts off so slow I don't have any urge to play for it. The characters are neat, but I wish I could interact with them more. If you want a good old shooter to waste some time, this game won't dissapoint. If you want the next big hit arena shooter, you're going to want to pass. It's hard to describe this game at all, watch some videos of it. 8/10.

reviewText:
I remember on January 2003, I got an early copy of Unreal 2 at Hastings, I'm guessing they had a review copy or something like that. Anyways, I remember playing it, liking it, but then again, I was 9 when I played it.

Now years later went by and I'm an adult now, is Unreal 2 as good as I remember it?

HELL NO.

Let's get the positives out of the way first, the graphics of Unreal 2 are good and weapons are unique just like the environments, from a gun that shoots spiders to a grenade launcher with multiple ammo types, the guns are good.

But that's about it.

Unreal 2's story has nothing in correlation with it's predecessor, Unreal 1 and RTNP.  In fact, the only thing that Unreal 1 and 2 have in common is the fact there's Skarrj, and that's about it. U2 does try to add Liandri, Izanagi and Unreal Tournament references in there, but it goes over the head like the comedy.

Characters are nice, but bland.

And then there's the gameplay.

U2 is single-player only (unless you get the XMP pack of the net), and while the environments are nice looking and unique, it doesn't help that each mission is about the same; go in, kill a bunch of dudes and aliens, solve a puzzle and get the artifact.

In between missions, you can talk to your crew aboard the USS Enter... I mean Atlantis, to get briefed about your next mission, learn about your weapons and learn about the backstory of the crew, that's it. It serves it's purpose.

But sometimes when normal missions aren't enough, U2 likes to throw a curve ball in the form of defense missions.. and these can BURN. IN. HELL.

Defense missions asks you to defend an area or a person for a certain amount of time, using force fields and turrets and Marines with Derpy AI to guard the objective from waves of enemies. The problem is that not only do they break the boring flow, but some of them are a pain, be it the derpy AI marines, the derpy targeting system of the Turrets, the fact that it takes little time for the enemy to plow through your defense with ease or all three.

And let's not forget that one DICKWAD on Janus named Meyer... The biggest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in U2 who constantly ♥♥♥♥♥es about everything. EVERYTHING.

With all these things combined, I cannot recommend Unreal 2: The Awakening to anyone, from veterans on Unreal to new players.
voteText: 6 of 17 people (35%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: Unreal 2 is an underrated little gem that was overshadowed by Halo (which in turn was influenced by the first Unreal). The major difference between the two is that while Halo sucks, Unreal 2 doesn't. The graphics are better, the combat is better and there are no tedious driving segments or pitiful attempts at an epic story with Disney enemies. The story is simple, involving chasing artefacts throughout the galaxy, which serves as an excuse to showcase some epic and varied environments that still impress. Despite the low-key story, there are some good character interactions and a very gutsy ending. The only downsides I can think of are the rather slow walking speed (a sprint function would have helped a lot) and a soundtrack that doesn't live up to its predecessor's reputation. Also note that the game's human enemies are annoyingly difficult on the hardest skill setting so take that as a word of caution if you're planning on yanking up the difficulty level.

reviewText:
Forget what the title says. Unreal II is not an Unreal game.

It's controls feel nothing like Unreal, it's weapons are nothing like Unreal and in general the atmosphere and design is a departure from anything previously made by either Epic Games or Digital Extremes. The sad thing about this sequel, besides soiling on the legacy of the franchise, is that even as a benchmark for the then new Unreal engine 2.0 it fails big time.

This wreteched entry deserves to put out of it's misery and forgotten for good, until it reappeared on Steam I was making a decent job of it too...

reviewText:
The biggest plus for Unreal II is that at its release it showed off the next step in graphics,at that time.
The game itself for me was horrible one one too many levels. Where to start?
Story: General and cheesy with low budget actors and no room for character development.
Weapons: While some have interest concepts, the weapons in this game feel like they do extremely low damage to every enemy.
Music: Generic and forgetable
I could go on like this with something negative about every aspect of the game.
To top it off the game is forcebly making the main character run VERY SLOW giving the idea that the game is longer than it actually is and surprise,it does not have a multiplayer which is the most interesting part of the Unreal series.
Do yourself a favour and stick to the Unreal Tournament series and give this one a pass.

reviewText:
Awful. A true insult to the Unreal series.

Unreal and Unreal Tournament are my two favourite FPS's of all time, Unreal offers a beautiful fast paced single player adventure with Awesome Multiplayer and Unreal Tournament IS Awesome Multiplayer. Unreal 2 is Neither.

This game has no reason bearing the name 'Unreal'. The ONLY connections to the previous games are a few similar weapons and the incredibly forced appearance of the Skaarj. That's it. The only other reason it has the name is because it uses the Unreal Engine, which is absolutely stupid, it would make as much sense calling XIII Unreal 3 or Dishonored Unreal 4!

Storywise the game offers nothing, you play as a generic Space Marine whose role is to fly around the universe with his Stripper/Captain, an engineer who was probably homeless before this job and the Unreal universes version of Jar Jar Binks. None of whom have much in the way of personality, general likability or interest.

Weapons in a Nutshell: The Dispersion Pistol from the first game, Except it can't be upgraded and is never used. A pistol which delivers a lot of damage but has low ammo, rarely used. A generic Assault Rifle (how creative). A shotgun that fires both regular rounds and fire rounds (kinda cool). A Flamethrower that can also fire flammable liquid and then be ignited (or you could just set the target of fire initially showoff). A Rocket launcher. A Sniper Rifle. A Gun that has interchangable rounds, yet you rarely find a use for each individual round, ultimately creating a mess of a weapon, 2 alien laser guns. A gun that shoots spiders (less coll than you would think). And a Black Hole Launcher that is only used in the last level.

There is an Escort mission in this game, and the guy you have to escort makes Natalya from Goldeneye seem like Elizabeth from Bioshock Infinite. He is such an annoying whiny ♥♥♥♥♥ and you just want to kill him, but killing the guy results in a game over. To rub it in your face, when you beat that level there is a cutscene where Blandy McSpace-Awesome is told to kill him, and he refuses, you don't even get a choice, you just watch as the game gives you the finger.

Levels are slow and empty, they usually contain few enemies, the game appears to be playing like Half-Life yet the enemies are all laid out like Splinter Cell, this is a Bad Thing. There is no exploration either, one of the things that made the first game so good was that you had to explore to survive, you found something new each time you played, this game does not, and as such has no replay value.

The Biggest sin of the game is that IT IS SOOOOOO SSLLLOOOOOWWWW. Your character moves like he is wearing Lead Armour and there are sections of the game that make you roam your ship just to talk initiate random chatter with people you don't care about, This coming from a series famous for it's fast action gameplay. Oh and the game is 6 HOURS LONG! The fact you move to slow feels like a cheap way to artificially lengthen the game.

To Spoil the ending (Because this is one of the worst games I have ever played); Your Crew gets killed (I think you are supposed to care) and you are then sent to see some alien mutate into an uncontrollable beast, This is the Final boss btw. When you kill it you get the aforementioned BFG Black Hole gun and you kill a bunch of identical and now inferior mutants, against an artificial timer as the ship heads to a sun. Oh and turns out some random guy you forgot about betrayed you and you kill him in a cutscene. Offscreen. You don't even get to see the impact. And you escape.

Honestly one of the Worst FPS games ever, and it's a shame because the developers clearly put more effort into the art design than the actual game. Yes, despite everything I've said the sole positive feature is that the game looks REALLY good. But other than that there is NOTHING. Oh and there is no Multiplayer either, yes, the series that managed to redefine multiplayer experience has a game with none at all. Perhaps if it an alternate name then perhaps it could jsut be forgotten about as a Generic FPS, but the fact it shares the name with two of my favourite games is insulting.

Don't buy this. Play Unreal or Unreal Tournament instead.

FINAL VERDICT: Garbage.

reviewText: Well, after finally beating this game, I liked it. In the regard that the developers stated this was a sequel to the first game, this game was sub-par and hardly lived up to the role of the previous installment. If taken as a separate game, I think it was good and still be considered a classic. I like the environments being large and consist of a variety of different themes to them. Although, the choice of how you want to approach the situation in the environments is usually limited beside the choice of what weapon to use in the approach. Also, this game, in comparison to Unreal: Gold, the levels seem to break up the game into levels. I think in the first installment, the game flowed like it was a sold experience that easily felt like one long campaign. Also, I can't go without mentioning that the levels seem short in general and for some reason, the load times are insane unless it is a short cutscene. The soundtrack is not a masterpiece but still fitting and good. The AI is still somewhat intelligent and can be funny at times. So, overall, I thought the game had some problems but it was still very enjoyable, I would play this game again and definitely would recommend this to fans of the series or first person shooter fans.

reviewText:
Unreal 2 The Awakening: This game is a true classic, good gfx and good story well put togeather Fps, old it may be but holds it head even today.
Its been some time ago since playing this game and i still have the retail version within my games collection, but like many other games on steam some are worth buying again so that you dont need to use your cd/dvd all the time.
Well my play time is not so high yet on steam but that will change soon as i need to tweak a few things first within the config file of the Ureal Engine.
My Os is win 7 64 bit with I7 processor 3.5ghz ATIGFX 4 gig card, and this game is for Win2000/XP 32 bit, with 32mb GFX card, the price of the game in sales was only £0.89  so thought its worth the risk on my new PC.
Game runs no problems but did want to change/tweak a few things within the Ureal Engine to get the best out of this classic game.

This may help some others run the game or not on older TVs? as my HDTV is old samsung it will only run games at its highest res of 1920-1080p at 30Hz :( or native res at 1280-720 HD at 60Hz.
Well within the game menu min refreshrate is set at min 60Hz up 85Hz so if you set game res within game to run in any res higher than 1280-720 the game will crashout out and give you error for your 3d

1. Look in C:\Program Files(x86)\Steamapps\Common.
2. Now look for Unreal II The awakening and open.
3. Look in System folder.
4. Scroll down to the file Unreal2 config
5. Now find and change to suit your system?

[WinDrv.WindowsClient]
WindowedViewportX=1024
WindowedViewportY=768
WindowedOffsetX=-1
WindowedOffsetY=-1
FullscreenViewportX=1920 Change to res you want here?
FullscreenViewportY=1080 Change to res you want here?

Next at 1920-1080 res on my tv the refreshrate within the game is set to min 60Hz, so i need to find it within the config file and change that.

Now scroll down and find it.

[D3DDrv.D3DRenderDevice]
UseHardwareTL=True
UseHardwareVS=True
UsePrecaching=True
UseTrilinear=True
UseVSync=True
UseTripleBuffering=False
UseCubemaps=True
ReduceMouseLag=True
AdapterNumber=-1
MaxTextures=0
MaxBlendStages=0
DesiredRefreshRate=30 Default is 60Hz min in the game menu but i need it to be 30Hz. change this to your DesiredRefreshRate?
UseStencil=False
DetailTextures=True
Use16bit=False
Use16bitTextures=False
UseCompressedLightmaps=False
LevelOfAnisotropy=16          Default here is set to 1 but i will change this to be 16 for best? check your GFX card for this.
DetailTexMipBias=0.800000
DefaultTexMipBias=-0.500000
AvoidHitches=False
DescFlags=0
Description=
HighDetailActors=True  This is set to default at false? change this to say True? i will check this one out again to see!!

So excellent all done for now hope this helps.
Would recommend this game to all FPS players its old but worth a score of 8/10 easy :)

reviewText:
This is a good FPS from it's time period, and is still playable on modern systems.

A lot of reviewers are complaining that you move too slow. I had the same issue. Even the very first level feels unbeatable at such slow speeds! It was frustrating! Fortunately, this game was created during a certain age in gaming that respected cheats instead of selling more powerful weapons and ammo or resources as PAID DLC. So here's how you fix the movement speed problem *spoiler alert: cheat codes ahead*

in the console (press ~ key to open) type bemymonkey" hit Enter-this enables cheats. Then type in "setspeed 1.5" and hit Enter again. You may want to set it to 2 or slightly higher if you want a more old-school
date: traditional dodge bullets instead of use cover FPS gameplay.\n\nThere you go
recommended: movespeed fixed and you can enjoy this game that actually has a lengthy campaign across several different interior and exterior settings/planets
hoursPlayed: a decent variety of weapons (with alt fire modes)
voteText: varied enemies
helpfulPercent: both human and lots of different aliens
votesHelpful: and passable graphics. Story is whatever
votesTotal: but if you want a good single player FPS with lots of different locations/planets that isn't Destiny's collection of horde modes in bite sited chunks everywhere in the galaxy
votesFunny: this is a good game to play.\n\nThe only cons for me were
column16: and it ended - no more sci fi adventure after you beat the game :("
